title: Deere Replaces CEO as Machinery Sales Sag
text:
Deere & Co. replaced long-time Chief Executive Samuel Allen with its chief operating officer, as it faces slack demand from struggling U.S. farmers and weaker sales than expected abroad.

The Moline, Ill., company said Thursday that John May will take over as chief executive of the world’s largest seller of farm machinery on Nov. 4. Mr. Allen, who has been CEO for a decade, will remain chairman. The transition has been expected by industry analysts, investors and employees since Mr. May’s promotion to COO in April.

Shares in Deere were up 2.46% to close at $156.48.

Mr. May, 50 years old, will take the helm of a company that has been backing away from aggressive global sales goals that Mr. Allen set early in his tenure. Mr. Allen, 66, had aimed for annual sales of Deere’s tractors, combines and other machinery to hit $50 billion through rapid growth to farmers in big emerging markets including China, India and Brazil. Each of those economies has cooled recently. Deere’s total sales last year were $37.3 billion. Equipment-industry analysts say Deere appears focused on reducing costs and using new technology to drive equipment sales in established markets like North America, where Deere commands 60% of the market for high-horsepower tractors. “They are going to stop chasing revenue,” said Rob Wertheimer, founding partner of Melius Research. “This is the turning of an era.” Mr. Allen was promoted to chief executive in April 2009 and oversaw one of the largest expansions of farm-equipment sales in the company’s 182-year history. But Deere struggled in the second half of his tenure with rising farm debt, falling farm incomes and trade tensions that have choked off U.S. exports to China in the past year. Falling prices for crops and livestock in recent years have weighed on machinery sales. Deere earlier this month trimmed its forecast for this year and reported quarterly sales of its farm equipment were 6% below the same period last year. Mr. May joined Deere 22 years ago and moved into the senior management team in 2012 as president of agricultural solutions and chief information officer. He managed Deere’s $305 million acquisition of Blue River Technology in 2017. The Silicon Valley company provided Deere with the foundation to offer customers machine-learning capabilities for applying herbicide to farm fields. Deere is working on sprayers that can distinguish weeds from crops when applying herbicide to fields, technology that Deere says would help farmers cut costs.
